metadata.title: Toxicity of differently sized and charged silver nanoparticles to yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae BY4741: a nano-biointeraction perspective

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 22 February 2019 Revised 18 April 2019 Accepted 28 April 2019
KEYWORDS Silver nanoparticles; toxicity; cell structure; confocal and electron microscopy

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Infections caused by microorganisms are often difficult to treat because microbes are rapidly able to adapt to conventional antibiotics (Huh and Kwon 2011). Therefore, there is a growing need for efficient antimicrobials to be applied on surfaces and materials (e.g. textiles, wound dressings, catheters, and implants), to suppress the growth of pathogens (Ahonen et al. 2017). One of the promising types of such antimicrobials is based on Ag nanoparticles (AgNPs) (Rai et al. 2014; Ahonen et al. 2017). Although the release of Ag ions, the cell membrane destabilization, interactions with thiol groups, inactivation of enzymes, and generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) are thought to play the key role in AgNPs antimicrobial action (Feng et al. 2000; Holt and Bard 2005; Marambio-Jones and Hoek 2010; Bondarenko, Juganson et al. 2013; Eckhardt
et al. 2013; Mijnendonckx et al. 2013; Ivask, Juganson et al. 2014; Rai et al. 2014; Le Ouay and Stellacci 2015), the full understanding on modulation of AgNPs biocidal potency by different physical-chemical properties of NPs is still missing.
As a rule, size and surface functionalization are parameters driving the interaction and antimicrobial effects of AgNPs. It has been clearly demonstrated that smaller AgNPs are more biocidal than bigger ones, mainly due to their higher solubility and bioavailability (Ma et al. 2012; Ivask, Kurvet et al. 2014; Kubo et al. 2018). Another key feature influencing AgNPs biocidal potency is their inorganic or organic surface coating which may modulate their colloidal stability, solubility and facilitate cellular interactions at the nano-bio interface (Bondarenko, Ivask et al. 2013; Ivask, Elbadawy et al. 2014; Suppi et al. 2015; K€aosaar et al. 2016). Indeed, higher antibacterial

potency of positively charged branched polyethylenimine (bPEI) coated AgNPs compared to negatively charged citrate- or polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) coated nanoparticles to Escherichia coli and Bacillus sp has been shown (El Badawy et al. 2011; Ivask, Elbadawy et al. 2014). However, not always the positively charged AgNPs proved more potent than negatively charged ones as shown by our recent study: within the same size category (10 and 50 nm) differently coated positively and negatively charged AgNPs had comparable toxicity towards bacteria Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus (Kubo et al. 2018).
However, the majority of information on AgNPs as well as on other antimicrobial NPs (e.g. ZnO, CuO) concerns bacteria and relatively little is known on the interaction and toxic effects of NPs to an important group of unicellular microorganisms— yeasts and fungi. Like bacteria, yeasts and fungi (e.g. Candida sp) can also cause serious infections and become drug resistant and therefore there is an emerging need for new effective antifungals (Perfect 2016). AgNPs are considered promising for prevention or treatment of both, bacterial and fungal infections (Dakal et al. 2016). Although unicellular yeast and fungal cells structurally differ from bacterial cells, similar toxicity mechanism of AgNPs both to bacteria and yeasts/fungi have been proposed, e.g. inactivation of enzymes, disruption of cell membrane, interfering with electron transport system, and increasing ROS production (Kim et al. 2009; Saulou et al. 2010; Niazi et al. 2011; Hwang et al. 2012; Bayat et al. 2014; Galv an M arquez et al. 2018). However, compared to bacteria, yeasts are generally less sensitive to AgNPs (Dorobantu et al. 2015; Suppi et al. 2015; Khatoon et al. 2017; Suvorov et al. 2017), most probably due to structural differences. Indeed, unlike bacteria, yeasts are eukaryotic organisms having e.g. nucleus, mitochondria, vesicular transport system, and vacuoles resembling the mammalian cell’s lysosomes. Importantly, yeasts have a rigid cell wall consisting of b-glucans, chitin and mannoproteins, and plasma membrane contains ergosterol (unlike mammalian cells having cholesterol).
Analogously to mammalian cells yeast cells have endocytosis (Shaw et al. 2001; Boettner, Chi, and Lemmon 2011; Epp et al. 2013). Even though intact yeast cells due to their rigid cell wall are not expected to internalize NPs, cellular uptake of
AgNPs by yeasts has been demonstrated (Bayat et al. 2014; Lara et al. 2015; K€aosaar et al. 2016).
In this study size and surface charge dependent toxicity of AgNPs to the yeast S. cerevisiae BY4741 was evaluated and backed up with the morphological analyses by scanning and transmission electron and confocal laser scanning microscopy (SEM, TEM, and CLSM, respectively) in order to elucidate the AgNPs-cell interactions. As mentioned above, S. cerevisiae is a unicellular eukaryotic organism having a lot of cellular and functional similarities with cells of higher-level organisms (e.g. oxidative stress response, aging, autophagy, etc.), and is therefore widely used model in cell biology and molecular studies (Kasemets et al. 2009). At the same time, S. cerevisiae is also a good fungal model having a cell wall and the ergosterol-containing cell membrane, which are one of the main specific molecular targets of the antifungal compounds. However, the design of novel efficient antifungals is quite challenging, as yeasts and fungi share a lot of similar traits with the eukaryotic cells of higher complexity. Therefore, the data on the size- and surface functionalization-driven cellular effects of AgNPs to S. cerevisiae could be informative to understand how these NPs properties may modulate their toxicity to the eukaryotic cells and drive their anti-yeast and anti-fungal potency.
For that, a set of AgNPs of two different primary sizes (10 nm and 80nm), coated either with citrate (yielding negative surface charge) or branched polyethylenimine-coated (yielding positive surface charge) were assessed for toxic effects and cellular interactions. AgNO3 as an ionic control was evaluated in parallel. SEM, TEM, and CLSM were applied to assess AgNPs-cell interactions and changes in cellular structure. As in our previous studies (Kasemets et al. 2013; K€aosaar et al. 2016), deionized (DI) water was used as a test medium to avoid the modulating effect of inorganic and organic ligands (present in the classical incubation media and buffers) on the physical-chemical properties of AgNPs (e.g. surface charge, size, solubility, and suspension stability).

sections.heading: Silver nanoparticles
sections.text:
Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs; 10 and 80 nm) coated by citrate (Cit) or branched polyethylenimine (bPEI)
were purchased from nanoComposix (Prague, Czech Republic; www.nanocomposix.eu) (BioPure line, sterile and endotoxin free, 1mg Ag/mL, Lot#: DAG1949, KJW1019, JMW1680, and JMW1712, respectively). AgNPs are hereinafter referred to as 10nAg-Cit, 80nAg-Cit, 10nAg-bPEI, and 80nAg-bPEI, respectively. According to the manufacturer’s datasheets, the primary sizes of 10nAg-Cit, 10nAg-bPEI, 80nAgCit, and 80nAg-bPEI were 10.0 ± 1.8, 8.8 ± 2.2, 77.1, and 83.4 ± 5.9 nm, respectively. The solvent of the citrate- or bPEI-coated AgNPs was aqueous 2mM citrate or deionized (DI) water (Milli-Q), respectively. Citrate- and bPEI-coated AgNPs suspensions’ pH was 10.2–10.5 and 7.4–7.6, respectively. AgNPs suspensions were stored at þ4 C in the dark.

sections.heading: Characterization of the Ag nanoparticles
sections.text:
The primary size and shape of AgNPs was examined by the Jeol JEM-1220 transmission electron microscopy (TEM) operating at 80 kV. Briefly, 5mL of AgNPs suspensions (100mg Ag/L in DI water) was deposited on a 200 mesh carbon-Formvar coated grids (200C-FC), and the samples were pre air-dried at room temperature (RT) before the TEM examination.
The hydrodynamic diameter (dH) and f-potential of AgNPs in DI water (18MX, pH 5.6 ± 0.1, Millipore) was measured using a Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern Instruments, UK). AgNPs were studied at the concentration of 50mg Ag/L in DI water after suspension preparation (0 h) and incubation for 24 h at 30 C.
Stability of AgNPs in DI water (10mg Ag/L) was studied by the ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectral analysis. The absorbance spectra were measured by the Multiskan Spectrum spectrophotometer (Thermo Electron Corporation, Finland) at the wavelengths of 300–800 nm (measurement step 5 nm) in 4mL polystyrene cuvettes at two time points: immediately after suspension preparation (0 h) and after incubation for 24 h at 30 C.
Quantification of dissolved silver ions
Dissolution of AgNPs in DI water was determined in abiotic conditions, i.e. without the presence of the yeast cells. AgNPs (1.0mg Ag/L) were incubated on the 12-well microplate (BD Falcon), 1.2mL per well at 30 C for 24 h. The nonsoluble fraction of AgNPs
was removed by the ultra-filtration tube of AmiconVR Ultra-4 3K (3000 MWCO) (Merck Millipore, Ireland), at the centrifugation speed of 7500 g for 40min at 30 C (Sigma 3-16PK, Germany). Filtrates were acidified by 65% HNO3 up to the concentration of 5% (v/v) and measured by atomic absorption spectroscopy (Varian SpectrAA 220) in Tallinn Technical University, Estonia.

sections.heading: Toxicity testing
sections.text:
Toxicity of 10 and 80 nm citrate- and bPEI-coated AgNPs was evaluated using yeast S. cerevisiae BY4741 wild-type cells (MATa; his3D1; leu2D0; met15D0; ura3D0) (EUROSCARF, Institute of Microbiology, University of Frankfurt, Germany). AgNO3 (Sigma-Aldrich) and bPEI (Sigma-Aldrich #408727, 1mg/L, provided by nanoComposix) were studied as ionic and bPEI-coating controls, respectively. Citrate toxicity as a coating control was not evaluated as citrate could be considered nontoxic to S. cerevisiae. Indeed, only very high concentration of citrate (50 g/L) inhibited the growth of S. cerevisiae by 80% (Nielsen and Arneborg 2007). For the comparison, according to the producer’s information citrate concentration of the citrate-coated AgNPs (1000mg Ag/L) was 378mg/L.
Toxicity experiments were conducted in DI water and performed as described by K€aosaar et al. (2016). Briefly, exponentially growing yeast cells in YPD medium were collected and washed twice in DI water and re-suspended in DI water to a cell density of OD600nm 1.2 ( 2 107 CFU/mL; CFU, colony forming unit). Then, 75 mL of the cell suspension was added into the wells of 96-well microplates (BD Falcon) containing 75 mL of AgNPs, AgNO3, or bPEI dilutions in DI water. AgNPs were tested between 0.01 and 100mg Ag/L, and AgNO3 and bPEI between 0.01–10mg (Ag)/L using first 10- fold and then 2-fold dilutions. The 96-well microplates were incubated without shaking at 30 C for 24 h. For the cell viability assessment the exposed and not-exposed (control) cell culture was diluted (decimal dilutions in 0.9% NaCl from 101 to 106), plated onto YPD-agar-plates and incubated for 48 h at 30 C. CFUs were counted and IC50 values for the tested toxicants (concentration of chemicals which reduced cell viability by 50% compared to the control) were calculated based on nominal
concentrations using the Log-normal model in the Excel macro REGTOX (http://www.normalesup.org/ vindimian/en_download.html). In addition, 5mL of the undiluted exposed and not-exposed (control) yeast culture was pipetted onto the surface of the toxicant-free YPD-agar plates and incubated for 48 h at 30 C and minimum biocidal concentration (MBC) was determined. MBC, the lowest tested concentration of the test compound which completely inhibited the post-exposure colony-forming ability of the yeast cells. Experiments were performed at least three times (two–three replicates per test) and the results were expressed as an average value ± standard deviation (SD).
Confocal laser scanning microscopy
In this study, confocal laser scanning microscope (CLSM) in the light reflection mode was used to examine the uptake of the studied AgNPs by the yeast cells. It has been shown that metal NPs scatter the light under the illumination and therefore the CLSM in the light reflection mode is useful for tracking of metal NPs within the cells (Paddock 2002; Braun et al. 2014; K€aosaar et al. 2016). For CLSM, the yeast cells (yeast culture was pre-cultivated and prepared as described in the previous section) were incubated without (control) or with the AgNPs or AgNO3 in DI water on 12-well microplates (BD Falcon) (1.2mL per well, 1.0 107 cells/ mL) for 24 h at 30 C. The following exposure concentrations were examined: 10nAg-bPEI and 10nAgCit, both at 0.1mg Ag/L (according to the manufacturer information, containing 2.8 1013 and 1.8 1013 particles/L, respectively), and 80nAg-bPEI and 80nAg-Cit, both at 1.0mg Ag/L (containing 3.3 1011 and 4.3 1011 particles/L, respectively) and AgNO3 at 0.05mg Ag/L. The above described Ag compounds exposure concentrations were used to keep the number of the particles of 10 and 80 nm AgNPs in the similar range, to meet the sensitivity of CLSM for the visualization of metal NPs by the laser reflection mode, but still keeping the toxicity of the studied Ag compounds lower than the respective IC50 or at least the MBC values. The same exposure concentrations were also used in the SEM and TEM experiments to compare the results obtained using different microscopy techniques.
After 24 h exposure to the studied Ag compounds the yeast cells were washed twice in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.4) and incubated in 50 nM mitochondria-specific red-fluorescent dye MitoTrackerVR Red (Molecular Probes) for 30min at 37 C in the dark, and then counter-stained by farred fluorescent 6.66 nM DRAQ5TM (BioStatus Ltd, DNA probe) for 3min at RT in the dark. Between each step the cells were washed in PBS and centrifuged at 6500 rpm for 5min. Finally, the cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 20min at RT, washed in PBS and suspended in 100mL DABCO (1,4- diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) mounting medium. Then, 5mL of cell suspension was deposited onto the SuperFrostVR Plus microscope slides (Menzel-Gl€aser) and covered by the cover-slips. A Leica TCS SP5 CLSM with reflected-light optics was used at a magnification of 40 (1.25NA Plan-Apochromat). Samples were illuminated with a 488nm Argon/Krypton laser using the 10% intensity of the AOTF filter. Images were processed with the LAS AF software (Leica).
Scanning and transmission electron microscopy
For the examination of AgNPs-cell interactions and yeast’s cell structure, SEM and TEM were applied. For that, the yeast cells were incubated without (control) or with the AgNPs or AgNO3 in DI water for 24 h at 30 C as described in the previous sections. All analytical-grade chemicals used for SEM and TEM sample preparation were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich unless noted otherwise.
For the SEM and TEM examination, exposed or not exposed yeast cells were washed once in DI water and then fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde in 0.1M sodium cacodylate buffer (pH 7.4) for 2 h at 4 C. After several washes with 0.1M sodium cacodylate buffer, cells were postfixed in 1% OsO4 in 0.1M cacodylate buffer for 1.5 h at RT, washed twice in DI water and dehydrated in graded ethanol solutions (from 25% to 100%), 10min in each solution. Between each of the steps, the cells were centrifuged at 6500 rpm for 5min (EppendorfTM 5424 Centrifuge, Thermo Fisher Scientific).
For the SEM examination, the ethanol-dehydrated yeast cells were further dried in the series of hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS)/ethanol mixtures (25%, 50%, and 75%, 10min in each mixture) and
finally in 100% HMDS (3 times, each 10min). Then, 50 mL of cell suspension in 100% HMDS was mounted on the aluminum stub (Ted Pella, USA/ Canada). After the overnight drying under the fume hood at RT, the samples were gold sputtered for 1min with an Edwards S 150B Sputter Coater and visualized by a Tescan VEGA TS 5136 XM scanning electron microscope operating at 20 kV and equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) detector (EDAX GENESIS 4000XMS).
For the TEM examination, the ethanol-dehydrated yeast cells were further treated in 100% propylene oxide (PO) for 2 10min and embedded gradually in Epoxy resin (Fluka Epoxy Embedding Medium), through a series of PO and resin mixture in volume proportions of 2:1 for 30min, 1:1 for 1 h, and 1:2 for overnight at room temperature (RT). Then the cells were embedded in 100% pure resin at RT for 4 h, and finally, the polymerization of resin was performed at 60 C for 48 h. Ultrathin sections of 70 nm of the resinembedded yeast cells were made on Leica-Reichert Ultracut E ultra-microtome and collected on 200 mesh copper grids (G200-Cu, EMS). Ultrathin sections of resin-embedded samples were not counterstained with uranyl acetate and lead citrate to avoid the interferences with the metallic NPs visualization (‘fake electron-dense nodules’). Cells were visualized by a Jeol JEM-1220 transmission electron microscope operating at 80 kV. For the detailed elemental analysis of AgNPs in contact with the yeast cells, bright field and then electron spectroscopic imaging (ESI) analyses were performed by a Leo912ab transmission electron microscope (Zeiss) at 80 kV. The element distribution (Ag) was obtained by computer processing of images collected at different energy loss values according to the three-window method. The final element map (coded in pseudo-colors) was then superimposed on the ultra-structural organization of the same field obtained at 250 eV. The nature of element signals in the different regions of the maps was confirmed by electron energy loss spectra. Digital images were acquired by CCD-BM/1K system and image elaboration was done by Esivision software.

sections.heading: Quantification of cell-associated Ag
sections.text:
For the quantification of cell-associated Ag (both, surface-bound, and intracellular), the yeast cells were exposed to 10nAg-bPEI, 10nAg-Cit, and
AgNO3 in DI water for 24 h at 30 C. Only 10 nm AgNPs were studied as according to preliminary experiments, 80 nm AgNPs (but not 10 nm AgNPs) tended to settle together with the yeast cells at the centrifugation speed of 3000–4000 rpm that was the lowest speed to obtain a stable yeast cells pellet for the next sample preparation steps. For the exposure experiments, exponentially growing yeast cells in YPD medium were collected and washed twice in DI water by centrifugation at 6500 rpm for 10min at RT (Sigma 3-16PK, Germany) and re-suspended in DI water to a final cell density of OD600nm 1.65 ( 2.75 107 CFU/mL). Experiments were performed in 250mL Erlenmeyer glass flasks, 50mL of yeast suspension per flask ( 1.37 109 CFU/50mL). Yeast cells were exposed to 0.1, 0.5, and 1.0mg Ag/L of 10nAg-Cit, 10nAg-bPEI, and AgNO3 for 24 h at 30 C in DI water. Although the examined concentrations of 10nAg-Cit and AgNO3 were already toxic to yeast, the lower concentrations were not studied as our preliminary experiments revealed (data not shown) that at the lower exposure concentration than 0.1mg Ag/L, the cellassociated Ag content was not anymore detectable by the applied method and equipment described below. After 24 h incubation, cells were washed twice in DI water by the centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 5min at RT in 50mL polypropylene centrifuge tubes (Falcon), and then resuspended in 1mL DI water, transferred into the 1.5mL preweight microtubes, centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 5min, and after discarding the supernatant, freeze-dried by the lyophilizer VirTis Sp Scientific Century 2 at –84 C and 20 mbar (vacuum) for 24 h. After that, the microtubes with lyophilized cells were weighed and the dry weight of the cells (dwt) was calculated. In the current experiments, the biomass of yeast cells was 14.2 ± 2.2mg dwt. Then, the lyophilized cells were solubilized/mineralized in 0.2mL of 65% HNO3 for 1 h, and evaporated at 80 C for 6 h in microtubes heater (self-made in NICPB), then solubilized in 1mL DI water and the vacuum evaporation was performed in the centrifugal vacuum concentrator (miVac Duo Concentrator). Finally, the obtained pellet was dissolved in 50 mL of 65% HNO3 supplemented with 1mg/L Ga standard. Exactly 10 mL of the sample was transferred on Picofox S2 quartz carriers (Bruker) and dried on a hotplate (60 C) for 10min. Ag was quantified by total reflection X-ray
fluorescence analysis using Bruker Picofox S2 in the saturated N2 environment. Ag concentration was calculated by the Bruker Spectra software. The detection limit of Ag was 1mg/L. Experiments were performed three to four times and results (mg Ag/mg dwt) were expressed as an average value±SD.

sections.text:
To determine statistically significant differences between the IC50 values and cell-associated Ag concentrations, t-test in Microsoft Excel 2010 was used. Statistical significance was accepted at p 0.05.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text: 10 and 80 nm citrate- and bPEI-coated AgNPs toxicity to yeast S. cerevisiae BY4741 was evaluated. SEM, TEM, and CLSM were applied for the examination of AgNPs-cell interactions and changes in cellular structure. All the experiments were conducted in DI water to prevent the interference of Ag with the organic and inorganic ligands usually present in the growth media and buffers and which may have modulating effect on the speciation of Ag ions as well as on AgNPs physicochemical properties, e.g. solubility, agglomeration, surface charge, and particle-cell interactions and consequently the toxicity (Zhang et al. 2011; Sharma et al. 2014; Suppi et al. 2015; K€aosaar et al. 2016). Our previous studies confirmed that in DI water the yeast S. cerevisiae cells stayed viable during 24-h incubation at 30 C (Kasemets et al. 2013; Suppi et al. 2015).

sections.heading: Physicochemical characterization of AgNPs
sections.text:
Physicochemical characteristics of 10 and 80 nm citrate- and bPEI-coated AgNPs are presented in Table 1. Primary sizes of the studied AgNPs according to manufacturer’s (nanoComposix) information were 10.0 ± 1.8 (10nAg-Cit), 8.80 ± 2.2 (10nAg-bPEI), 77.1 ± 1.1 (80nAg-Cit), and 83.4 ± 5.9 nm (80nAgbPEI). Our TEM examination showed the spherical shape of the AgNPs (Figure 1(A)), and the primary sizes measured by Image J software were 11.1 ± 2.0, 9.93 ± 2.3, 73.4 ± 6.70, and 79.2 ± 5.9 for 10nAg-Cit, 10nAg-bPEI, 80nAg-Cit, and 80nAg-bPEI, respectively (Table 1, Supporting Information Figure S1), being coherent with the manufacturer information.
According to the TEM micrographs, bPEI-coated AgNPs were as single particles, but citrate-coated NPs appeared in clusters (Figure 1(A)). However, the hydrodynamic diameter measurement did not reveal the agglomeration of the citrate-coated AgNPs in DI water: average hydrodynamic size (dH) after making of suspensions (0h) was 14.6 ± 0.6 (10nAg-Cit), 26.4± 4.7 (10nAg-bPEI), 85.0 ± 3.3 (80nAg-Cit), and 108±4.6nm (80nAg-bPEI), and did not change during 24h incubation at 30 C (Table 1). Polydispersity indices (PdI) were not exceeding 0.26 confirming the monodisperse nature of the studied AgNPs suspensions (Table 1). In the same size category, bPEIcoated AgNPs had bigger dH than citrate-coated AgNPs, probably due to the differences in the particles’ capping agent molecular masses (Mw of bPEI and sodium citrate were 25 000 and 258.07 g/mol, respectively). f-potential (0 h) values were –19.9 and –35.4mV for 10nAg-Cit and 80nAg-Cit (negatively charged AgNPs), and þ21.5 and þ43.2mV for 10nAg-bPEI and 80nAg-bPEI (positively charged AgNPs). Differently from the 80nm AgNPs, f-potential of 10 nm AgNPs increased to some extent during the 24-h incubation at 30 C (Table 1).
UV-visible (UV-Vis) absorbance spectra of 10 and 80 nm AgNPs (10mg Ag/L) showed the characteristic localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) peaks at 390–405 and 450–465 nm, respectively (Figure 1(B)). LSPR peaks did not shift during the 24-h incubation in DI water at 30 C, indicating the stability of the AgNPs suspension (no increase in the particle size). Same results were obtained also by the dH measurement during the 24-h incubation (Table 1). Differently from the rest of studied AgNPs, 10nAg-Cit maximum absorbance value (ODmax) at the LSPRmax (kmax 390 nm) decreased
after 24-h incubation (from 1.36 to 1.00) in DI water at 30 C (Figure 1(B)). As 10nAg-Cit LSPR curve’s shape (e.g. width) and kmax did not change, a decrease in the ODmax value indicated the dissolution of AgNPs (Zook et al. 2011).
AgNPs dissolution in DI water at the concentration of 1mg Ag/L was quantified under the same test conditions as toxicity experiments, with one exception—the yeast cells were not present. The presence of yeast cells may have led to the underestimation of the solubility of AgNPs as S. cerevisiae is well known for its heavy metals biosorption capacity. 10nAg-Cit, 80nAg-Cit, 10nAg-bPEI, and 80nAgbPEI solubility was 36.8 ± 3.7, 3.18 ± 0.8, 1.81 ± 0.8, and 1.25 ± 0.5%, respectively (Table 1). Thus, 10 nm AgNPs were more soluble than 80 nm AgNPs whereas the difference was more remarkable for citrate- ( 11.5 times) than for BPEI-coated AgNPs ( 1.5 times). Within the same coating category, the citrate-coated AgNPs were more soluble than bPEIcoated AgNPs (Table 1). Interestingly, 10nAg-Cit solubility was 37%, being higher than previously reported values for the same sized citrate-, casein-, or PVP-coated AgNPs in DI water, remaining typically in 1.3–8.3% range (Ivask, Kurvet et al. 2014; K€aosaar et al. 2016; Kubo et al. 2018).
Toxicity of AgNPs to yeast S. cerevisiae
Dose-dependent toxicity of all the studied AgNPs to S. cerevisiae was observed after 24-h exposure in DI water at 30 C (Figure 2). The order of toxicity
(according to the 24-h IC50 values, mg Ag/L) was as follows: 10nAg-bPEI>AgNO3 > 80nAg-bPEI > 10nAg-Cit > 80nAg-Cit (Figure 3(A)). Thus, the most toxic Ag-compound was 10nAg-bPEI being even statistically more toxic than AgNO3 (IC50 0.04 ± 0.01 and 0.07 ± 0.01mg Ag/L, respectively, p< 0.05) (Figure 3(A)). However, 24-h MBC values (Figure 3(B)) showed that the most toxic was AgNO3 followed by 10nAg-bPEI (MBC 0.5 and 1.0mg Ag/L, respectively) and the MBC values of the rest of the studied Ag-compounds were similar to the order of IC50 (Figure 3(A)). Within the same coating category (citrate or bPEI), 10-nm AgNPs were more toxic than 80 nm AgNPs and in the same size category (10 or 80 nm) bPEI-coated AgNPs were more toxic than citrate-coated AgNPs (Figure 3). Differences in the toxicities (24 h IC50) between 10nAg-bPEI and 80nAg-bPEI, and 10nAg-Cit and 80nAg-Cit were 5- and 27-fold, respectively, showing bigger sizedependent toxicity of the citrate-coated AgNPs than bPEI-coated ones. However, if we corrected the 24-h IC50 values of AgNPs in respect to the specific surface area (SSA) (Table 1), the results (Supporting Information Figure S2) showed that still, the size effect was prominent for the citrate-coated AgNPs (10nAg-Cit were 4-times more potent than 80nAgCit), but 10 nm and 80nm bPEI-coated AgNPs had at the comparable specific surface areas (0.002 and 0.001m2/g, respectively) similar toxic effect (decrease in cell viability by 50%) Interestingly, the 80nAg-bPEI was even more potent than 10nAg-bPEI ( 2 times) according to the SSA-corrected IC50

In summary, the most prominent effect on the toxicity of the differently sized and coated AgNPs was caused by the coating, i.e. positively charged bPEI-coated AgNPs were more potent toward yeast cells than negatively charged citrate-coated AgNPs within the same size category and 80nAg-bPEI was even more toxic than 10nAg-Cit (Figure 3, Supporting Information Figure S2).
To reveal the possible role of shed Ag ions in the overall toxicity, the solubility of AgNPs was quantified and the respective nominal IC50 values were corrected according to the dissolved fraction of AgNPs (Figure 4 and Supporting Information Table S1). AgNO3 was considered to be 100% dissolved in DI water. The dissolution corrected IC50 values of 10nAg-Cit and 80nAg-Cit (0.11 and 0.26mg Ag/L, respectively) were comparable or even higher than the respective AgNO3 IC50 value (0.07mg Ag/L), revealing that the toxicity of citrate-coated AgNPs was mainly caused by shed Ag ions. However, the toxicity of bPEI-coated AgNPs was not possible to explain by the dissolved Ag fraction (Figure 4 and Supporting Information Table S1). Indeed, the dissolution corrected IC50 values of 10nAg-bPEI and 80nAg-bPEI were 0.001 and 0.002mg Ag/L, being 30–70 times lower than the respective IC50 of AgNO3 (0.07mg Ag/L). Thus, the positively charged bPEI-coated AgNPs should have the particle-driven effects to the cells (e.g. binding onto the surface of cells facilitating the cellular internalization and/or dissolution in the close vicinity of the cells wall).
Furthermore, the toxicity of bPEI as a coating was also examined to clarify its possible role in the overall toxicity of bPEI-coated AgNPs. 24-h IC50 and MBC values of bPEI were 0.18 ± 0.07 and 5.0mg/L, respectively (Figure 2 and Supporting Information Figure S3). sections.heading: S. cerevisiae
sections.text:
CLSM images are presented in Figure 5 and Supporting Information Figure S4. In the CLSM study AgNPs intercellular location was examined by the laser reflection mode (Figure 5(A1–F1), ‘white spots’) and yeast cells were stained/visualized by the mitochondria- and DNA-specific fluorescent probes MitoTrackerVR Red (Figure 5(A2–F2), red color) and DRAQ5TM (Figure 5(A3–F3), blue pseudo-color), respectively.
Laser (light) reflection analysis revealed the intracellular location of all the studied AgNPs after 24-h exposure in DI water at 30 C, despite their size and charge (see the ‘white spots’ in Figure 5(C1–F1, C4–F4) and Supporting Information Figure S4), but not in the control cells (Figure 5(A1, A4)) and cells exposed to AgNO3 (Figure 5(B1, B4)). Cross-sectional analysis (Z stack) of yeast cells showed that after exposure to 10 and 80nm citrate- and bPEI-coated AgNPs, the AgNPs were inside the cells, and only in the case of 80nAgbPEI, the cell surface-bound AgNPs were also detectable (Supporting Information Figure S4).
De novo formation of AgNPs from Ag ions within the yeast cells exposed either to the AgNO3 or AgNPs releasing Ag ions has been demonstrated (Despax et al. 2011; Vazquez-Mu~noz et al. 2014). However, in our study the ‘white spots’ (i.e. metal NPs) in the AgNO3-exposed yeast cells were not detected (Figure 5(B1, B4)) indicating that in the current exposure and CLSM visualization conditions the de novo (bio)synthesis of AgNPs from
bioavailable Ag ions did not occur. Hence, the intracellular location of AgNPs in the AgNPs-treated yeast cells (Figure 5 and Supporting Information Figure S4) should be rather the result of the uptake of the particles than the consequence of the uptake of the solubilized Ag ions and de novo formation of NPs. Indeed, yeast cells have energy-dependent clathrin-mediated endocytosis (Boettner et al. 2011) and End3p-mediated uptake of Au, CdSe, and Ag NPs by the yeast spheroplasts or intact cells has been shown (Prescianotto-Baschong and Riezman 1998; Sun et al. 2014; K€aosaar et al. 2016).
CLSM images showed that 10nAg-bPEI (0.1mg/L) exposed yeast cells exhibited weaker red (Figure 5(D2)) and blue signal/color (Figure 5(D3)) than the control or yeast cells exposed to the rest of studied Ag compounds (Figure 5). MitoTrackerVR Red accumulation in the cells depends on the mitochondria membrane potential and the decrease in the red signal intensity may refer to the dysfunction of mitochondria and increased ROS production (Fr€ohlich, 2012). 80nAg-bPEI (1.0mg Ag/L) did not exhibit a similar effect on mitochondria than 10nAg-bPEI (Figure 5(F2)). However, the 80nAg-bPEI exposed yeast cells showed the chromatin condensation (Figure 5(F3)). Chromatin condensation and nuclear fragmentation is a sign of apoptosis (Sun et al. 2014; K€aosaar et al. 2016). Above described 10 and 80 nm bPEI-coated AgNPs cellular effects could be due to the fact that the studied concentrations (0.1 and 1.0mg Ag/L, respectively) caused 80% decrease in the cell viability, but 10 and 80 nm citrate-AgNPs (0.1 and 1.0mg Ag/L) and AgNO3 (0.05mg Ag/L) 20–35%, respectively (Figures 1 and 3). Still, the bPEI-AgNPs at the similar equitoxic concentrations had a different effect, 80 nm AgNPs induced the chromatin condensation and 10 nm NPs not (Figure 5(D3, F3)), and 10 nm AgNPs had the effect on the mitochondria and 80 nm not (Figure 5(D2, F2)).

SEM-EDX was performed. Interestingly, it was not possible to map the presence of Ag in the ‘surfaceadsorbed-granules’ (data not shown), probably due to the low sensitivity of the applied technique to map the small-sized AgNPs at low exposure concentrations (0.1 or 1.0mg/L, respectively) or,
alternatively, the observed ‘granules’ were not the bPEI-coated AgNPs but rather the changed cell surface morphology. Changes of the cell surface of Candida albicans from smooth to rough after exposure to the positively charged AgNPs has been demonstrated (Lara et al. 2015). Changes in the cell

AgNPs-cell interactions and cell structure analysis by TEM
The bright-field TEM observations (Figures 7–9) of yeast cells exposed to the 10 and 80 nm bPEI- and citrate-coated AgNPs were coherent with the SEM results (Figure 6): upon exposure to bPEI-coated AgNPs it was possible to detect the ‘electron-dense granules’ (probably AgNPs), adsorbed onto the cell surface (Figure 8), but not upon exposure to citratecoated AgNPs (Figure 9). To confirm the bPEIcoated AgNPs adsorption onto the cell surface, elemental mapping of Ag by the ESI-TEM was performed. ESI-TEM analysis confirmed the presence of Ag in the ‘cell-bound particles’ (electron-dense granules) (Supporting Information Figure S5). However, in the case of 80nAg-bPEI exposed cells (but not 10nAg-bPEI exposed cells) it was possible to map clearly the presence of Ag (Supporting Information Figure S5). The lack of sensitivity in the
latter case was probably due to the low number of Ag atoms contained in a single 10 nm AgNPs. Moreover, ESI-TEM revealed the abundant intracellular accumulation of Ag after 24-h exposure to both bPEI-coated AgNPs (Supporting Information Figure 5S) confirming the results of the CLSM study.
After exposure to 80nAg-bPEI, ‘electron-dense granules’ were also visible at the cell wall periphery (Figure 8(B2, B3)) and within the cytoplasm (Figure 8(B1–B3)). Analogous effects were not observed for 10nAg-bPEI exposed cells (Figure 8(A1–A3)), probably due to the small size of the particles. However, ESI-TEM and CLSM clearly confirmed the intracellular location of the 10nAgbPEI after 24 h exposure (Supporting Information Figures 4S and 5S). Unlike 80nAg-bPEI, 10nAg-bPEI exposure resulted in the irregular shape of the yeast cells and swollen cell wall (Figure 8(A1)). One of the main differences in the cell structure after exposure to the bPEI-coated AgNPs (Figure 8) compared to the control (Figure 7) and citrate-coated AgNPs exposed cells (Figure 9) was the lack of clearly distinguished vacuoles in bPEI-AgNPs

Positively charged NPs, especially bPEI-coated NPs may have the Hþ buffering capacity and may cause the swelling and disruption of endosomes/ vacuoles (proton sponge effect) and endosomal escape, resulting in the leakage of hydrolytic enzymes and NPs accumulation in the cytosol
(Fr€ohlich, 2012; Smith et al. 2018). Hypothetically, the endosomal escape phenomenon can also be the explanation, why we were not able to detect vacuoles in the yeast cells exposed to the bPEIcoated AgNPs (Figure 8). Thus, the SEM and TEM results (Figures 6 and 8) revealed that the adsorption of bPEI-coated AgNPs onto the surface of the yeast cells could explain the higher toxicity of these AgNPs. Indeed, the release of Ag ions (which is considered the main antimicrobial action of AgNPs), explained only the citrate- but not bPEI-coated AgNPs toxicity to S. cerevisiae (Figure 4, Supporting Information Table S1).
However, the charge itself (negative or positive) is not the only particles surface-binding determinant, but also the charge values/densities and differences between the NPs and cells’ surface charges (Nomura et al. 2013; Feng et al. 2015). Nomura et al. (2013) showed that only p-amine-polystyrene NPs with f-potential of þ39mV and not the same particles having f-potential of þ14mV, adsorbed onto the surface of yeast cells and induced cell death. Likewise, Lyden et al. (2017) showed that positively charged amine-polystyrene NPs having

For control cells (not exposed), see Figure 7. Exposure of yeast cells to 10nAg-Cit, 80n-Ag-Cit and AgNO3 induced similar ultrastructural changes: enlarged “empty” vacuoles, containing “black electron-dense deposits” (probably silver-bound non functional cell components; see the white arrows). In the case of 10nAg-Cit, some vacuoles were filled with non-homogeneous content (A1, A3). There was no evidence of the AgNPs adsorption onto the surface of cells (no presence of the cell surface bound electron dense “granules”). In the current study f-potentials of 10nAg-Cit, 80nAg-Cit, 10nAg-bPEI and 80nAg-bPEI in DI water were –33.1, –38.7, þ36.6, and þ46.7mV, respectively (Table 1) and only the bPEI-coated AgNPs adsorbed onto the surface of the yeast cells (Figures 6 and 8).
TEM observations revealed that differently from bPEI-coated AgNPs, citrate-coated AgNPs and exposure to AgNO3 caused an increase in the size of vacuoles (Figure 9). Similar ultrastructure changes upon exposure to AgNO3 and citrate-coated AgNPs could indicate the same mode of action of these Ag compounds. Indeed, the toxicity of 10 and 80 nm citrate-coated AgNPs was explainable by the shed Ag ions (Figure 4, Supporting Information Table S1). Vacuoles in the yeast cells are the main vesicular transport target organelles, resembling the lysosomes of the mammalian cells, having a large variety of macromolecules degrading capacity but also proteins and ions storage function (Li and Kane 2009). Increase in the size of the vacuoles is characteristic stress-response of yeast at the ionic stress conditions (Li and Kane 2009). TEM observation of 10nAg-Cit, 80nAg-Cit, and, AgNO3 exposed cells showed the presence of the dark/black electron dense area in the vacuoles (border of the vacuoles, see the white arrows in Figure 9). Silver has a high affinity for the sulfur compounds (Eckhardt et al. 2013) and the formation of silver-thiol-groups-containing proteins complexes may cause the proteins misfolding, subsequent non-functionality and degradation in the vacuoles. Moreover, silver has also high affinity to the phosphorus compounds and yeast vacuoles contain a lot of phosphorous (Li and Kane 2009). Hypothetically these black electrondense areas in the vacuoles (Figure 9) may contain Ag-protein and Ag-phosphorous complexes.

sections.heading: Quantification of cell-associated Ag concentration
sections.text:
To evaluate how the surface coating (and charge) may modulate AgNPs cellular uptake and bioavailability, cell-associated Ag (both, intracellular and surface-bound) was quantified after yeast cells ( 1.37 109) exposure to 10nAg-Cit and 10nAgbPEI in DI water for 24 h at 30 C. Only 10 nm AgNPs were studied as 80 nm AgNPs tended to cosettle during the centrifugation of the cell-AgNPs
suspension after 24-h exposure and therefore could have affected the results (i.e. overestimation of the cell-associated Ag content). For the comparison, the cellular uptake of AgNO3 (free Ag ions) was also assessed. Results showed that at the same exposure concentration (0.5 or 1.0mg Ag/L) 10nAg-bPEI was statistically more cell-associated (bioavailable) than 10nAg-Cit ( 4 times) (Figure 10). Thus, although the 10nAg-Cit was more soluble than 10nAg-bPEI (Table 1), the citrate-coated AgNPs were less bioavailable (and also less toxic, Figure 3) than bPEIcoated AgNPs. Apparently, the positively charged AgNPs attached more efficiently on the negatively charged yeast cells’ surface, leading to the enhanced uptake and higher cell-associated Ag content. Indeed, in DI water Z-potential of yeast S. cerevisiae BY4741 was –37.0mV (Kasemets et al. 2013) and the SEM and TEM analysis revealed the bPEI-coated AgNPs and not the citrate-coated AgNPs adsorption onto the surface of the yeast cells (Figures 6, 8, and 9). The results of the study showed that the higher bioavailability of AgNPs is important for the more efficient fungicidal potency and that the adsorption onto the cell surface is a prerequisite to increase AgNPs bioavailability in the yeast cells.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
Toxicity evaluation clearly revealed the size- and surface charge dependent toxicity of AgNPs to S. cerevisiae. Within the same coating category, 10 nm AgNPs were more potent than 80 nm, and within the same size category, the positively charged bPEI-AgNPs were more potent than negatively charged citrate-AgNPs (Figure 3). Surface charge effect on the toxicity of AgNPs to yeast was more prominent than the size effect. Indeed, 80nAg-bPEI was even more toxic than 10nAg-Cit (Figure 3).
CLSM revealed the intracellular location of all the studied AgNPs (Figure 5; Supporting Information S4) whatever the size and coating of AgNPs. In our previous study we showed the uptake of 10 nm AgNPs by the yeast cells was mediated by End3p (K€aosaar et al. 2016). However, SEM and TEM observation revealed that only bPEI-coated, contrary to citrate-coated AgNPs, adsorbed onto the surface of yeast cells (Figures 6, 8, and 9). Moreover, differently from bPEI-AgNPs exposure, citrate-AgNPs and AgNO3 caused an increase in the vacuole size indicating the similar toxicity mechanisms (Figure 9). Enlargement of vacuoles is a characteristic cellular response of yeasts to ionic stress (Li and Kane 2009). Indeed, quantification of dissolution of AgNPs revealed that the toxicity of citrate-coated AgNPs (but not bPEI-coated NPs) was due to the shed Ag ions (Figure 4; Supporting Information Table S1). Cell-bound Ag quantification showed that at the same exposure concentration (0.5 or 1.0mg Ag/L), 10nAg-bPEI was statistically more bioavailable (cell-associated) than 10nAg-Cit ( 4-times) (Figure 10), most likely due to the positive-charge facilitated absorbance onto the negatively charged yeast’s cell wall. Thus differently from negatively charged citrate-AgNPs, toxicity of positively charged bPEI-AgNPs was mostly particle-driven leading to internalization and/or to more pronounced dissolution of AgNPs in the close vicinity of the cell wall.
In conclusion, the systematic examination of differently sized and coated AgNPs revealed that the size, coating, and charge of AgNPs can be used for the design of new more efficient antifungals, but the surface charge of AgNPs seems to be even more potent toxicity modulating characteristic than the particle size.

metadata.abstractText: In the current study, we evaluated the modulatory effects of size and surface coating/charge of AgNPs on their toxicity to a unicellular yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae BY4741 – a fungal model. For that, the toxicity of a set of 10 and 80nm citrate-coated (negatively charged) and branched polyethylenimine (bPEI) coated (positively charged) AgNPs was evaluated in parallel with AgNO3 as ionic control. Yeast cells were exposed to different concentrations of studied compounds in deionized water for 24h at 30 C and evaluated for the viability by the post-exposure colonyforming ability. Particle-cell interactions were assessed by SEM, TEM and confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) in the reflection mode. AgNPs toxicity to yeast was size and charge-dependent: 24-h IC50 values ranged from 0.04 (10nAg-bPEI) up to 8.3mg Ag/L (80nAg-Cit). 10 nm AgNPs were 5–27 times more toxic than 80nm AgNPs and bPEI-AgNPs 8–44 times more toxic than citrate-AgNPs. SEM and TEM visualization showed that bPEI-AgNPs but not citrate-AgNPs adsorbed onto the yeast cell’s surface. However, according to CLSM all the studied AgNPs, whatever the size and coating, ended up within the yeast cell. Toxicity of citrate-AgNPs was largely explained by the dissolved Ag ions but the bPEI-AgNPs showed mainly particle-driven effects leading to the cellular internalization and/or to more pronounced dissolution of AgNPs in the close vicinity of the cell wall. Therefore, the size, and especially the coating/charge of AgNPs can be efficiently used for the design of new more efficient antifungals.
